paper_metadata.title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe

authors.name: Penske, Sandra
authors.affiliation: Department of Archaeogenetics, Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology, Leipzig, Germany

authors.name: Rohrlach, Adam B.
authors.affiliation: Department of Archaeogenetics, Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology, Leipzig, Germany; School of Computer and Mathematical Sciences, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, South Australia, Australia

authors.name: Childebayeva, Ainash
authors.affiliation: Department of Archaeogenetics, Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology, Leipzig, Germany

authors.name: Ross, Shawn
authors.affiliation: Department of History and Archaeology, Macquarie University, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

authors.name: Haak, Wolfgang
authors.affiliation: Department of Archaeogenetics, Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology, Leipzig, Germany

paper_metadata.notes: Nature paper reporting 135 ancient genomes from southeastern Europe spanning 5400-2400 BC. Multi-institutional collaboration across 8 countries.

orcid_coverage.notes: No ORCIDs found in PDF text. Nature often requires ORCIDs but they may be in online version metadata only, not printed in PDF. Surprising for 2023 Nature paper with 18 authors from multiple institutions.

dataset_pids.dataset_description: DNA sequences for 135 ancient individuals (genome-wide data, 1.24 million SNP panel)

linked_in_paper.verbatim_quote: The DNA sequences reported in this paper have been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive under the accession number PRJEB62503.

pid_graph_summary.notes: Paper DOI + dataset accession number present. No author ORCIDs found in PDF. No software PIDs (uses standard bioinformatics tools). PID connectivity typical for 2023 genomics paper in Nature.

funding.verbatim_text: This research was funded by the Max Planck Society
the European Research Council under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement nos 771234-PALEoRIDER, W.H.)
funding.notes: ERC Horizon 2020 grant to Wolfgang Haak
ERC Horizon 2020 grant to S.H. (likely Svend Hansen based on author list)
ERC Horizon 2020 grant to P.W.S. (Philipp W. Stockhammer)

funding.verbatim_text: the ERA.Net RUS Plus initiative (S&T-277-BIOARCCAUCASUS, S.H.)

data_availability.verbatim_statement: The DNA sequences reported in this paper have been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive under the accession number PRJEB62503.

repositories.dataset_description: DNA sequences for 135 ancient individuals, genome-wide data enriched for 1.24 million SNPs

F_findable.F1_rationale: ENA accession number PRJEB62503 is a persistent identifier for nucleotide sequence data.
F_findable.F2_rationale: ENA provides rich structured metadata for sequence submissions including sample metadata, study design, taxonomic information.
F_findable.F3_rationale: ENA metadata explicitly includes accession numbers and links to related identifiers.
F_findable.F4_rationale: ENA is indexed by multiple services (INSDC, NCBI, DataCite). Searchable via accession number and metadata fields.

A_accessible.A1_rationale: HTTPS access via ENA website and FTP. Standard retrieval protocols.
A_accessible.A1_1_rationale: ENA is freely accessible, no authentication required for public data.
A_accessible.A1_2_rationale: Not applicable - data is fully open.
A_accessible.A2_rationale: ENA commits to long-term metadata preservation as part of INSDC (International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration).

I_interoperable.I1_rationale: ENA data in FASTQ, BAM, CRAM formats with standardised XML metadata. Machine-parseable.
I_interoperable.I2_rationale: ENA uses controlled vocabularies (INSDC taxonomy, ontologies for sample attributes, experimental design).
I_interoperable.I3_rationale: ENA links to paper DOI, sample accessions, related datasets. Typed relationships in XML metadata.

R_reusable.R1_rationale: ENA requires extensive sample metadata (geographic origin, temporal context, sequencing protocols, quality metrics).
R_reusable.R1_1_rationale: Paper published under CC-BY-4.0 (stated in article). ENA data typically CC0 or unrestricted for sequence data.
R_reusable.R1_2_rationale: ENA metadata documents sample provenance, DNA extraction protocols, library preparation methods, sequencing platform.
R_reusable.R1_3_rationale: Follows INSDC standards for nucleotide sequence data. Ancient DNA community standards for authentication (damage patterns, contamination estimates).

machine_actionability.rationale: ENA provides API access, structured XML metadata, standardised file formats (FASTQ, BAM). Fully machine-actionable via ENA APIs and FTP.

discipline_context.baseline_comparison: Ancient DNA papers in high-profile journals (Nature, Science, Cell) typically achieve 13-15/15 FAIR scores with domain-specific repositories (ENA, SRA, EMBL). This paper (14/15) exemplifies field best practices.
discipline_context.expectations_rationale: Ancient DNA field has strong data sharing norms driven by: (1) community standards (INSDC), (2) journal requirements (Nature mandates data deposition), (3) funding requirements (ERC requires open data).

data_availability.notes: Data FAIR score: 14/15 (93.3% - highly FAIR). Exemplary data sharing practice typical for 2023 Nature genomics paper. ENA accession enables full data reuse with rich metadata and community standards compliance.

computational_reproducibility.rationale: No custom code shared. Paper uses standard bioinformatics tools and pipelines (EAGER, GLIMPSE, hapROH, ancIBD, ANGSD, bcftools, samtools, etc.) with published implementations. Methods describe tool versions and parameters but no custom scripts provided. Typical for ancient DNA genomics papers using established workflows.

environment_specification.notes: No computational environment specification. Tool versions documented in Methods (GLIMPSE v.1.0.1, HapROH v.0.64, ancIBD v.0.4, etc.) enabling manual pipeline reconstruction.

analysis_transparency.notes: Methods extensively documented with parameters for each analysis step. Software tools cited with version numbers. Workflow clear but not scripted. No random seeds mentioned for stochastic processes (imputation, admixture modelling).

fair_assessment.rationale: No code availability statement. Paper relies on published bioinformatics tools rather than custom scripts, which is standard practice in ancient DNA genomics. Tools themselves are FAIR (published software with DOIs/URLs) but no project-specific analysis scripts shared.

code_availability.notes: Code sharing not expected for this paper type. Ancient DNA genomics typically uses standard pipelines (EAGER, nf-core/eager) and published tools. Computational reproducibility achieved through detailed Methods rather than shared scripts. Contrast with software-focused papers (Ballsun-Stanton 2018) where code is primary output.

author_contributions.verbatim_statement: W.H., S.H., P.W.S. and J.K. designed the study. R.K., G.G.-R., C.S., M.A.S., G.U.N., A. Chohadzhiev, A.S., K.P., S.R., M.L., I.M., B.G., K. Boyadzhiev, Y.B., K. Beutler and I.B. provided materials and resources. S.P. performed laboratory experiments. S.P., A.B.R., G.G.-R., C.S., G.U.N. and A. Childebayeva analysed the data. W.H., I.M., S.H., P.W.S., Y.B. and K. Boyadzhiev assisted with data interpretation. S.P., S.H., P.W.S., I.M., A.B.R. and W.H. wrote the manuscript with contributions from all co-authors.
author_contributions.notes: Detailed CReDIT-style author contributions typical for Nature papers. 18 authors with clear role delineation. Archaeological collaborators (excavators, museum directors) are co-authors providing materials/resources and expertise.

conflicts_of_interest.verbatim_text: The authors declare no competing interests.
conflicts_of_interest.notes: Standard Nature competing interests statement. No conflicts declared.

ethics_approval.verbatim_text: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study.
ethics_approval.ethics_body: Multiple (excavators, curators, museum directors as co-authors)
ethics_approval.notes: Ancient human DNA research. Permission granted by site authorities (excavators, curators, museum directors) who are co-authors. Standard practice for ancient DNA papers - permissions granted by institutions controlling human remains. Ethical approval for ancient remains typically handled through institutional authorities rather than ethics committees (unlike living human subjects research).

permits.verbatim_text: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study.

permits_and_authorizations.notes: Permission statement covers 8 archaeological sites across 4 countries (Bulgaria: Varna, Yunatsite, Tell Petko Karavelovo, Boyanovovo, Majaky; Romania: Pietrele; Ukraine: Usatove; Moldova: sites from Manzura). Institutional approvals from multiple museums and archaeological authorities. Co-authorship of site excavators/curators demonstrates proper authorization.

preregistration.notes: No preregistration mentioned. Not standard practice for ancient DNA genomics papers in 2023.

materials.description: Extensive supplementary tables (A through Y, at least 25 tables) with sample metadata, genetic data, statistical results
Extended Data Figures (at least 9 figures) with additional analyses and results

supplementary_materials.notes: Extensive supplementary materials typical for Nature papers. Referenced throughout main text (Supplementary Tables A-Y, Extended Data Figs 1-9, Supplementary Information sections 1-6). Includes sample metadata, genetic statistics, quality control metrics, archaeological context.

references_completeness.notes: References section appears comprehensive (94 numbered references in PDF). High DOI usage expected for Nature paper. Formal assessment deferred to validation pass.

primary_gaps: No author ORCIDs found in PDF
No code availability statement (uses standard tools)
strengths: DNA sequences in ENA with accession number (PRJEB62503)
Multiple funding sources acknowledged with grant numbers
fair_assessment.notes: Exemplary FAIR compliance for 2023 Nature genomics paper. Data FAIR score 14/15 (93.3%) reflects ancient DNA field best practices: domain-specific repository (ENA), persistent accession number, rich metadata, community standards. Code sharing not applicable (uses standard bioinformatics pipelines). Infrastructure stronger than typical HASS paper (Sobotkova 2024: 4/15) due to: (1) high-profile journal requirements, (2) genomics community norms, (3) ERC funding mandates.

extraction_notes: Nature paper with extensive infrastructure documentation typical for high-profile journal
Data in ENA with accession number - exemplary FAIR compliance (14/15)
No code shared (uses standard bioinformatics tools) - typical for ancient DNA genomics
No ORCIDs found in PDF despite Nature guidelines - may be in online version only
18 authors from 8 countries - major multi-institutional collaboration
Permission statement for ancient human DNA analysis - ethical approval via institutional authorities (excavators/curators as co-authors)
5 major funding sources: Max Planck Society + 3 ERC grants + ERA.Net RUS Plus
113 new radiocarbon dates reported alongside genetic data
Extensive supplementary materials (25+ tables, 9+ figures, 6 information sections)
Contrast with previous papers: Ballsun-Stanton 2018 (code-focused, 13/15 FAIR), Sobotkova 2024 (methods-focused, 4/15 FAIR), Penske 2023 (data-focused, 14/15 FAIR)
Ancient DNA field shows strong FAIR adoption driven by community standards, journal requirements, funding mandates
